title: Defining the Slang Phrase "Body Tea" (Plus, Where It Came From)

steps.title: TikTok User @queenoppss first used the term in July 2023.
steps.content: TikTok User @queenoppss first used the term in July 2023. The post was a clip from one of her livestreams. It featured her praising one of her friends by saying, â€œShe get money. Her body tea. Sheâ€™s super thicc. Sheâ€™s super pretty.â€ [3] X Research source The clip caught on with other users and got over 750,000 views in the next 8 months. â€œBody teaâ€ spread to other social media sites like X, Reddit, and Instagram, often shared with images of users and celebrities describing their bodies as hot. steps.title: By early 2024, the term was so popular it inspired parody posts.
steps.content: By early 2024, the term was so popular it inspired parody posts. In March 2024, X user @MatthewKBegbie posted an image of Mrs. Potts from Disneyâ€™s animated film Beauty and the Beast with the caption, â€œher body is tea.â€ The post earned over 7,500 likes in 5 days. steps.title: Some believe the phrase came from the slang term â€œspill the tea.â€
steps.content: Some believe the phrase came from the slang term â€œspill the tea.â€ â€œSpill the tea,â€ meaning to share gossip or other intriguing news has been an extremely popular slang term. It comes from African American Vernacular English (AAVE), most likely from drag culture before spreading to the mainstream on TV shows like RuPaul's Drag Race and social media. [4] X Research source The 1994 non-fiction book Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil quotes drag queen Lady Chablis as using the term â€œTâ€ to stand for her truth. [5] X Research source However, the evolution from â€œspill the teaâ€ to â€œbody teaâ€ isnâ€™t clear, and they may not be related.

steps.title: @queenoppssâ€™s original post has become a lip dub meme.
steps.content: @queenoppssâ€™s original post has become a lip dub meme. A lip dub was originally a type DIY music video people made with them lip-syncing to a popular song and posting on YouTube. Lip dubs were also made of cartoon characters dubbed with pop songs or other dialog. [6] X Research source When the trend moved to TikTok, users also used clips of audio from other TikTok posts to create a meme, which is what happened with @queenoppssâ€™s post. As early as July 2023, TikTok user @ldr1437 shared a video of a kitten with the original voiceover from @queenoppssâ€™s clip. The first viral lip dub video featured an office staff lip-syncing to Harvey Dangerâ€™s â€œFlagpole Sitta.â€
